newsitem.title: UK: HORSE RACING-SLEEPYTIME GIVES CECIL FIFTH 1,000 GUINEAS WINNER.
newsitem.headline: HORSE RACING-SLEEPYTIME GIVES CECIL FIFTH 1,000 GUINEAS WINNER.

text.p: Sleepytime gave trainer Henry Cecil his fifth 1,000 Guineas success when running home an effortless four lengths winner of the first fillies' classic of the season on Sunday.

The 5-1 shot, a brilliant performer on the gallops who had been unlucky in her last two runs, defeated the 50-1 shot Oh Nellie with the 16-1 chance Dazzle three quarters of a length further back in third.

The victory by Sleepytime was a first British classic success for Irish jockey Kieren Fallon. Cecil, given a rousing reception in the Newmarket paddock afterwards, was full of praise for his new stable jockey.
"He is very hard-working and dedicated -- a good horseman," he said. "I'm thrilled with the filly and the jockey."
French raider Pas de Reponse, the 5-2 favourite, was kept well up to the pace in the 15 horse field but Freddie Head found that the filly ran out of stamina up the Newmarket hill.
The quietly spoken Fallon said of Sleepytime: "She came good in the end. I had a nice handy position, I got around them and she ran on well. When you are travelling well the gaps open."

Both Cecil and Fallon felt that Sleepytime still had plenty of improvement in her but Cecil believed the filly would not stay beyond a mile and a quarter (2-km). He may now give her a rest until Royal Ascot in June.

Oh Nellie, ridden by Willie Ryan, sprang from the stalls ahead of Sarayir, Bianca Nera and Pas de Reponse. Fallon, sharply criticised when Sleepytime failed to get a clear run in her trial race at Newbury last month, made no mistake this time.
Fallon hit the front inside the last furlong (200 metres) and powered up the hill for what was a decisive and impressive victory.

Sleepytime, by the Irish stallion Royal Academy, proved a good pick for Fallon who could have also ridden Cecil's two also rans -- Yashmak and Reams of Verse --- who are both recovering from bouts of coughing.
Frankie Dettori had won the first three races of the day and betting shop owners all around Britain were beginning to fear a repeat of last year's Ascot's triumph when he won all seven races.
But his Guineas mount Moonlight Paradise spared the bookies the betting blow they dreaded by finishing out of the places.
